title-group.article-title: Opine biosynthesis in naturally transgenic plants: Genes and products

kwd.tp:taxon-name: Rhizobium rhizogenes (Riker et al., 1930) Young et al., 2001 ( Rhizobiaceae )
C. gronovii Willd. ex Roem. & Schult.
Allorhizobium undicola de Lajudie et al. 1998

sec.title: N/A
sec.p: Opine biosynthesis in naturally transgenic plants: Genes and products
Tatiana Matveeva a, * , L´eon Otten b
a St. Petersburg State University, University Emb., 7/9, Saint Petersburg , Russia

b
Institute of Plant Molecular Biology, C.N.R.S, 67084, Strasbourg, France
ARTICLE INFO

sec.title: N/A
sec.p: ABSTRACT

The plant pathogen
Agrobacterium
transfers DNA into plant cells by a specific transfer mechanism. Expression of this transferred DNA or T-DNA leads to crown gall tumors or abnormal, hairy roots and the synthesis of specific compounds, called opines. Opines are produced from common plant metabolites like sugars, amino acids and α- keto acids, which are combined into different low molecular weight structures by T-DNA-encoded opine synthase enzymes. Opines can be converted back by
Agrobacterium
into the original metabolites and used for agrobacterial growth. Recently it has been discovered that about 7% of Angiosperms carry T-DNA-like sequences. These result from ancient
Agrobacterium
transformation events, followed by spontaneous regeneration of transformed cells into natural genetically transformed organisms (nGMOs). Nearly all nGMOs identified up to date carry opine synthesis genes, several of these are intact and potentially encode opine synthesis. So far, only tobacco and cuscuta have been demonstrated to contain opines. Whereas opines from crown gall and hairy root tissues have been studied for over 60 years, those from the nGMOs remain to be explored.

sec.title: Keywords:

p.tp:taxon-name: Rhizobium rhizogenes (Riker et al., 1930) Young et al., 2001 ( Rhizobiaceae )

sec.p: Horizontal gene transfer
Natural genetically modified organisms Opines
Opine synthases
T-DNAs

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p:
For a long time, the nomenclature and classification of
Agrobacterium
was based on the characteristics of the diseases they cause (Binns and Costantino, 1998). Thus, the bacteria leading to the development of crown galls were called
Agrobacterium tumefaciens
, and those that caused the development of hairy roots were attributed to
A. rhizogenes
, and their plasmids were called Ti- (tumor inducing) and Ri- (root inducing) plasmids respectively. Some species were named after the plants they infect, like
A. vitis
and
A. rubi
. Based on phylogenetic studies,
Agrobacterium species
have been reclassified as
Rhizobium , Allorhizobium , Ahrensia
,
Pseudorhodobacter
,
Ruegeria
, and
Stappia
(Young et al., 2001, 2003; Farrand et al., 2003; Mousavi et al., 2015). Thus, after a new taxonomic revision, representatives of
A. tumefaciens
were classified as
Rhizobium radiobacter (Young et al., 2001)
, then based on genomic data several
Rhizobium species
were transferred back to the genus
Agrobacterium
, which currently contains the old species
A. radiobacter , A. tumefaciens , A. rubi
and
A. larrymoorei
(Ormeno-Orrillo et al., 2015; Flores-F´elix et al., 2020).
A. rhizogenes
was renamed as
Rhizobium rhizogenes (Young et al., 2001)
, and
A. vitis
renamed as
Allorhizobium vitis (Mousavi et al., 2015)
. Thus, the taxonomy of
Agrobacterium
/
Rhizobium
is still fully in development and current naming is still controversial. Also, most literature references use the traditional names. Therefore, we will use the more familiar names
A. tumefaciens
,
A. rhizogenes
and
A. vitis
.

Surprisingly, regeneration of whole plants from tissues transformed by
Agrobacterium
can occur not only in the laboratory, but also under natural conditions. Indeed, early in
Agrobacterium
research, some plant species were found to contain T-DNA-like sequences in their genomes (
,
). This T-DNA was named cellular T-DNA (cT-DNA), and such plants were called naturally transgenic plants or natural genetically modified organisms (nGMOs).

sec.title: 2. The history of the discovery of naturally transgenic plants
sec.p:
The detection of cT-DNA sequences in various
Nicotiana species
raised the question how widespread this phenomenon is outside the genus
Nicotiana
and the Solanaceae family.

The next important step in studying the extent of horizontal gene transfer from
Agrobacterium
to plants was made with the detailed studies by Chen et al. (2014, 2018), based on the early studies on various
Nicotiana species.
Deep sequencing of several
Nicotiana species
within the subgenus Tabacum led to the discovery of five cT-DNAs (TA, TB, TC, TD, TE), different from the
N. glauca
cT-DNA.
N. tomentosiformis Goodsp.
and
N. kawakamii Y. Ohashi
carry TA, TB, TC, and TD (Chen et al., 2014).
N. tomentosa Ruiz & Pav.
contains TB, TC, and TD,
N. tabacum
L. has TA, TB, and TD (Chen et al., 2014).
N . otophora Griseb
(Сhen et al., 2014, 2018). carries two dissimilar copies of a TC and TE cT-DNA. TE is specific to
N. otophora
and copy TE1 contains acs, iaaH, iaaM, 6b, ocs /
vis
,
rolB, rolC, orf13, orf13a, orf14, mas 2
’,
and
mas 1
’
, organized as a double inverted repeat. TE2 is a shortened version of TE1 with its center deleted. The nucleotide divergence between the cT-DNA repeats was used to date the different inserts, and to establish their order of insertion (Chen et al., 2014). A further cT-DNA was found in
N. noctiflora Hook.
, its map remains to be established (
).

Almost all
Nicotiana
cT-DNA structures contain unusual genes or gene combinations. The TA insert has unusual orf14 and mis genes. TB carries a orf1 4-mis fragment, similar to part of the T-DNA of strain 1724, and a fragment with mannopine and agropine synthesis genes (
mas 2
′
- mas 1
′ -ags ). The TC insert is similar to the left part of the
A. rhizogenes
A4 T-DNA and is flanked by an octopine synthase-like (
ocl
) sequence on the left and a c -like gene (both typical for
A. tumefaciens
) on the right. TD has a T-DNA fragment similar to that of the right end of the TL-DNA of the
A. rhizogenes
strain A4, and a new gene orf511 with unknown function between the well-known orf14 and orf15 genes (Chen et al., 2014). TE contains two parts, one similar to
A. tumefaciens
T-DNA, the other to
A. rhizogenes
T-DNA (Chen et al., 2018). These observations suggest that we still know little about the natural diversity of
Agrobacterium
strains and their T-DNAs. Thus, as new T-DNA genes are discovered, the search criteria for new natural GMOs have to be regularly adapted.

The idea of horizontal gene transfer by
Agrobacterium
was further confirmed by the fortuitous discovery of another example of naturally transgenic plants, namely, species within the
Ipomoea
genus (
). Small interfering RNAs (siRNAs) analysis from
Ipomoea batatas
(L.) Lam. (sweet potato) showed the presence of T-DNA sequences. This led to the detection of two types of cT-DNA at different loci of the
Ipomoea batatas
genome. IbTDNA1 is polymorphic among sweet potato cultivars. IbTDNA2 contains typical
A. rhizogenes
genes and an unusual type of rolB/C -like gene. Both T-DNA types are arranged as inverted repeats (
; Quispe et al., 2019). Later a third IbTDNA3 with
mas 2
’
and
mas 1
’
genes was identified by bioinformatic methods (
).

A new stage in the targeted search for natural GMOs became possible through the development of genomic sequencing and bioinformatics methods (
): a further two dozen species were described within the genera
Eutrema , Arachis , Nissolia , Quillaja , Euphorbia , Parasponia , Trema , Humulus , Psidium , Eugenia , Juglans , Azadirachta , Silene , Dianthus , Vaccinium , Camellia
,
Cuscuta
,
Aeschynomene , Salix , Luffa , Cyclocarya , Citrus, Campotheca , Diospyros , Dioscorea ,
and
Musa
. In 2020, more species were added to this list. They belong to genera
Aeschynomene , Eperua , Eucalyptus , Boswellia , Kewa , Pharnaceum , Nyssa ,
and
Populus ( Matveeva, 2021 )
. All nGMOs, except the banana-related
Musa acuminata Colla
and the greater yam (
Dioscorea
) are dicotyledonous. The taxonomic position of the greater yam as a monocot is debated.

The new examples of natural transformants showed that as much as 7% of dicotyledonous species are naturally transformed plants, and provide valuable material for studying the role of horizontal gene transfer in plant evolution (
). Importantly, whereas most other cases of horizontal gene transfer are due to accidental DNA transfer, with presumably little consequences for the host, the
Agrobacterium
T-DNA genes are transferred by a special mechanism, and modify the host in several ways.

These results also show that
Agrobacterium
-mediated plant transformation is a natural process which has occurred on a large scale in nature for millions of years. Thus it becomes increasingly difficult to maintain that plant genetic engineering is based on an artificial, unnatural technique.

sec.title: 3. The importance of opine synthase genes in nGMOs
4. Opines and opine synthases
sec.p:
Opines owe their name to D(+)-octopine, or N 2 - (1-D-carboxyethyl)- L-arginine from
Octopus vulgaris ( Morizawa, 1927 )
. This compound (1) is formed in cephalopods during anaerobic oxidation of glucose (Hochacka et al., 1977) by octopine dehydrogenase (ODH or OcDH) through the condensation of pyruvate and L-arginine into a Schiff’ s base, followed by reduction to octopine. Various related compounds (all condensation products with pyruvate) have been found in marine animals, like alanopine (amino acid moiety: L-alanine), β- alanopine (β- alanine), tauropine (taurine), strombine (glycine), and seropine (L-serine), and are collectively called opines; their general structure can be described as N-(carboxyalkyl)amino acids, or N-(CA)amino acids (
). The N-(CA)amino acids are products of the NAD(P) H-dependent reductive condensation between an α- keto acid and the α- or ω- NH2 group of an amino acid, and show two asymmetric centers with either (L,L) or (D,L) stereochemistry. The corresponding enzymes are called opine dehydrogenases (OpDH). The animal OpDH enzymes (also called pyruvate reductases, G¨ade and Grieshaber, 1986) fall into two classes: a mollusc-annelid-type OpDH related to ODH, and a sponge-type OpDH (like tauropine dehydrogenase from
Halichondria japonica (Kadota, 1922))
structurally related to ornithine cyclodeaminase and alanine dehydrogenase (Kan-no et al., 2005; Vasquez-- Dorado et al., 2013). Additional opines are saccharopine, staphylopine, yersinopine and others (MacFarlane et al., 2018).

In the case of the crown gall and hairy root opines, opines fulfill a different role and include several compounds which do not correspond to the N-(CA)amino acid formula. Their definition has become a functional, rather than structural one.
Agrobacterium
-related opines have been defined as strain-specific metabolites, which can be detected in crown gall and hairy root, and are degraded by the corresponding bacterial strains (Isogai et al., 1988). Some compounds synthesized by transformed cells, like methiopine, cannot be used by the bacterium, and have therefore been called pseudo-opines (Firmin et al., 1985). It was found later that methiopine induces the octopine catabolism operon occ via the transcription factor OccR (Flores-Mireles, 2012). Whether the definition of opines requires that they should be absent from normal plant tissues or not, is not clear, but several authors (Tempe´and
; Bates et al., 1984; Chilton et al., 1995) have used such a more restricted definition. In the early days of
Agrobacterium
research (before 1977), the unprecedented proposal that
Agrobacterium
transfers genes into plants, and that they are expressed and lead to opine synthesis, was met with much scepticism. It was reported that opines could also be found in normal plant tissues, and their large amounts in crown gall tissues were thought to result from the tumorous growth conditions (
; Ackermann et al., 1973; Wendt-Gallitelli and Dobrigkeit, 1973;
;
; Christou et al., 1986). Technical improvements in opine detection showed that various results for normal plants were due to artefacts. It was therefore proposed that opines are reliable markers for crown gall and hairy roots and do not occur in normal plant tissues (
; Holderbach and Beiderbeck, 1976; Baldwin et al., 1978; Tempe´and
; Dessaux and Petit, 1994). Conclusive evidence for gene transfer was provided by molecular data (Chilton et al., 1977), and by the localization of the octopine synthase gene ( ocs , Schr¨oder et al., 1981) and nopaline synthase gene ( nos , Depicker et al., 1982; Bevan et al., 1983) on T-DNAs. However, we now know that a sizeable proportion of Angiosperms contain intact opine synthesis genes derived from
Agrobacterium
-mediated transformation events (
), and that tobacco (Chen et al., 2016) and
Cuscuta suaveolens Ser (Zhang et al., 2020b)
. contain opines. Thus, opines can no longer be considered to be specific for crown gall and hairy root tissues. The production of deoxyfructosylglutamine (DFG) (9) by a T-DNA-encoded enzyme, Mas2’, raises another problem. DFG is also found in normal plants, where it can be produced by a non-enzymatic Amadori reaction (
). Finally, compounds produced by
Rhizobium
in symbiosis with plants, have also been called opines (
), although they do not result from gene transfer. Because of these exceptions, we propose here a somewhat different definition for
Agrobacterium
-related opines: opines are compounds that are synthesized by T-DNA-encoded enzymes, and which can in most cases be metabolized by
Agrobacterium
, or used for gene regulation. In the following chapter we will present the different types of opine synthases and their products. A summary of reactions leading to opines is presented in Supplementary Figure 1.
4.1. octopine and vitopine synthases

Polyclonal Ocs antibodies have been obtained (Goldmann et al., 1981). Purified Ocs accepts pyruvate (to a lesser extent α- ketobutyrate), L-lysine, L-arginine, L-ornithine, L-histidine, L-methionine and L-glutamine, the preferred cofactor is NADPH (
; Hack and
). Later it was found that octopine crown gall tumors of
Helianthus annuus
L. (sunflower) also contain the L-glutamine derivative, called heliopine. Mutation of ocs by Tn5 insertion at its 3 ′ end changed the substrate specificity of the Ocs enzyme: tumors not only contained octopine and heliopine, but also N 2 -(1,3-D-dicarboxypropyl)-L-asparagine or asparaginopine (the latter is generally called succinamopine, Chang et al., 1989). Ocs can further use S-methylmethionine (SMM) as a substrate, leading to N -(D-1-carboxyethyl)-S-methyl-L-methionine or sulfonopine, which
Agrobacterium
can use as a sulphur source (Flores-Mireles et al., 2012). The same authors found that Ocs can also use homocysteine, canavanine, homoserine, cysteine, glycine, and homoarginine as substrates, possibly leading to substantial amounts of the corresponding opines in species rich in such compounds. Canavanooctopine was detected in tumors of
Canavalia ensiformis ( Petit et al., 1968 )
. Ocs from
A. vitis
strain AB3 is 86% identical to the classical Ocs. Its substrate specificity is different: it does not use methionine or ornithine (
). Animal ODH enzymes also have different substrate specificities (Gade ¨and Grieshaber, 1986; Coughlan et al., 1996).

Vitopine (2) was first described in grapevine tumors induced by
A. vitis
strain S4 (
), and later found to be identical to heliopine (Chilton et al., 2001). Vitopine synthase (Vis) is related to Ocs. Its enzymatic properties have not been studied sofar. Another opine, R -rid´eopine, was identified in S4 tumors. Its structure, N -(4 ′ -aminobutyl)-D-glutamic acid, is derived from putrescine and L-glutamic acid (Chilton et al., 2001). The name of this opine refers to the french phytobacteriologist Michel Ride´(1923–2011) who collected and studied many
A. vitis
isolates. Whether this opine is synthesized by vitopine synthase or by another enzyme (possibly encoded by the S4 lsn gene) is unknown.
4.2. Nopaline synthase

Sterile crown gall tumor tissues of the cactus
Opuntia vulgaris Mill.
(nopal in french) did not contain pyruvate-derived opines, but a new compound: the reduced condensation product of α- ketoglutarate and Larginine, called N 2 -(1,3-D-dicarboxypropyl)-L-arginine or nopaline (3) (Goldmann et al., 1969). Nopaline can be spontaneously lactamized to pyronopaline under acidic conditions and can be degraded by
Agrobacterium (Hall et al., 1983)
. The strict relation between the inciting
Agrobacterium
strains and the opines found in the corresponding tumors was an important argument for the proposal that crown galls resulted from DNA transfer from the bacterium to the plant (
), and that opine synthesis was of benefit to the bacterium and the “raison d’ˆetre" of the T-DNA transfer mechanism (
,b).

sec.title: 4.3. Cucumopine synthase
sec.p:
Cucumopine (5) was discovered in hairy root cultures induced by
A. rhizogenes
strain NCPPB2655 on cucumber (Davioud et al., 1988), and in grapevine tumors induced by
A. vitis
(Petit and Temp´e, 1985). It is a condensation product of L-histidine and α- ketoglutarate which is not further reduced like most other opines, but cyclized by a Pictet-Spengler reaction. The cucumopine synthase ( cus ) gene has been identified on the NCPPB2655 T-DNA (Brevet et al., 1988) and
A. vitis Tm
4 TB-DNA (Fournier et al., 1993). An in vitro assay with the NCPPB2659 Cus enzyme (produced in
E. coli
) yielded cucumopine (
).

sec.title: 4.4. Mikimopine synthase
sec.p:
Mikimopine (6) was found in hairy roots induced by
A. rhizogenes
strain NIAES1724 (Isogai et al., 1988, 1990). It is a diastereoisomer of cucumopine, and mikimopine synthase (Mis) shows some similarity to Cus at its C-terminal end (
). Expression of 1724-mis in
E. coli
and an in vitro assay led to the production of mikimopine (
).
4.5. D,L-succinamopine synthase (SusD)

Succinamopine, or N 2 -(1,3-D-dicarboxyl)-L-asparagine (7a), and its derivatives succinamopine lactam and succinopine lactam (Chang and Chen, 1983; Chilton et al., 1984a, 1984b) were discovered in AT181 and EU6 tumors. The succinamopine structure is derived from α- ketoglutarate (like nopaline) and L-asparagine. Succinamopine and nopaline belong to the glutamyl-type opines which also include nopalinic acid, L, L-succinamopine, leucinopine, mannopine and mannopinic acid. All undergo easy lactamisation. AT181 tumors also contain N 2 -(1, 3-D-dicarboxyl)-L-glutamine or glutaminopine. Both succinamopine and glutaminopine could be obtained with crude enzyme assays or by incubation of tumor tissue with radioactive substrates (Chang and Chen, 1983). Later it was found that succinamopine from AT181 tumors has the usual (D,L) form of most other opines, whereas Bo542 tumors contain the epimer, L,L-succinamopine (7b) (Chilton et al., 1985b, see below). The corresponding genes and enzymes were called susD /SusD and susL /SusL for D,L- and L,L-succinamopine respectively (
). SusD of AT181 (Blundy et al., 1986) is related to octopine, vitopine and nopaline synthases.
4.6. L,L-succinamopine synthase (SusL) and ornithine cyclodeaminase (RolD)

Tumors induced by
A. tumefaciens
strain Bo542 contain L,Lsuccinamopine or Lglu , Lasp- succinamopine (Chilton et al., 1985b). They were previously reported to contain L,L-leucinopine or N -(1,3-D-dicarboxyl)-L-leucine (8) (Chang et al., 1983; Chilton et al., 1985a). L, L-succinamopine might be the major opine produced in Bo542 tumors (Chilton et al., 1985b). Both L,L-succinamopine and L,L-leucinopine are synthesized by SusL (L,L-succinamopine synthase, also called leucinopine synthase or Les). Chry5-TL has a very similar susL gene. SusL is related to RolD (Chry5-SusL/A4-RolD: 47% identity), which itself is homologous to ornithine cyclodeaminase (OCD, see below). It is unclear what kind of enzymatic reactions OCD and SusL may have in common. Interestingly, it has been noted (Kan-no et al., 2005) that tauropine dehydrogenase (TaDH) from
Halichondria japonica
is homologous to OCD and differs from the other animal OpDH enzymes.

rolD (root locus D, also called orf15 ) genes are found on T-DNAs of several
A. rhizogenes
strains. rolD from
A. rhizogenes
strain A4 plays a role in hairy root growth since an A4 rolD mutant induces callus instead of root growth on
Kalanchoe daigremontiana
leaves (
). RolD is similar to ornithine cyclodeaminase (Ocd or OCD) enzymes from various rhizobacteria (37% identity to Ocd WP_168711323.1 from the
Sinorhizobium
/
Ensifer
group) and, like Ocd, converts ornithine into proline (
). The agrobacterial octopine degradation pathway also shows this activity (catalyzed by ArcB). The role of rolD in hairy roots and
Agrobacterium
growth is not clear. Normal plants do not contain Ocd activity, instead, ornithine to proline conversion is carried out by enzymes which require pyrodoxal phosphate (
).
A. rhizogenes
strain 15834 possesses two orf15 genes, orf15-1 and orf15-2 . The orf15-2 region was earlier reported to contain orf18 and orf17n (
), but a recent sequence (SGOF01000008.1:65513-66562) shows only one gene.

sec.title: 4.7. Mannityl opine enzymes
sec.p:
After the initial discoveries of the octopine and nopaline families, a new type of opine was discovered in octopine tumors, called agropine. The amounts (7% of tumor dry weight) were described as “prodigious” (Firmin and Fenwick, 1978). Agropine is a 1,2 ′ -lactone cyclisation product of N 2 -(1 ′ -deoxy-D-mannit-1 ′ -yl)-L-glutamine (
). Its synthesis requires three genes, encoding three successive enzyme reactions (Ellis et al., 1984). The gene and enzyme names are unusual and require some explanation. The octopine-type Ti plasmid pTiAch5 carries two T-DNAs, TL and TR.TR contains 4 genes, called 4 ′ , 3 ′ , 2 ′ , 1 ′ , and
0 ’
(from left border to right border,
; Ellis et al., 1984), in order to distinguish them from the TL genes ( 1–7 ). After gene 2 ′ , 1 ′ and 0 ′ were shown to be involved in mannopine and agropine synthesis, their names were changed to
mas 2
’
,
mas 1
’
(or
mas 2
and
mas 1
) and ags (or
mas 0
′ ). Mas2 ′ catalyzes the reductive condensation of D-glucose and L-glutamine (or L-glutamic acid) to N 2 -(1 ′ -deoxy-D-fructos-1 ′ -yl)-L-glutamine, also called deoxyfructosylglutamine or dfg, or santhopine (9), and N -(1 ′ -deoxy-D-fructos-1 ′ -yl)-L-glutamic acid or deoxyfructosylglutamic acid (10), respectively. Mas1 ′ is a reductase, converting dfg and deoxyfructosylglutamic acid into N 2 -(1 ′ -deoxy-D-mannit-1 ′ -yl)-L-glutamine or mannopine (11) and N -(1 ′ -deoxy-D-mannit-1 ′ -yl)-L-glutamic acid or mannopinic acid (12) respectively. Finally, Ags lactonizes mannopine into the 1–2 ′ -delta-lactone of mannopine, called agropine (13) (Ellis et al., 1984; Dessaux et al., 1986). Agropine was also discovered in tumors which did not contain octopine or nopaline (Guyon et al., 1980) and in hairy root tissues (Tepfer and Tempe´, 1981). Some
A. rhizogenes
strains, like 8196, contain a T-DNA with
mas 2
’
and
mas 1
’
, but ags is lacking (Hansen et al., 1991). 8196 induces hairy roots with mannopine, mannopinic acid and N -(1 ′ -deoxy-D-mannit-1 ′ -yl)-5-oxo-L-proline or agropinic acid (14), a lactamisation product of mannopine (Dessaux et al., 1992), but no agropine. Mannopine accumulates to high levels; its contents vary between 0.2 and 1% of the hairy root fresh weight (
).

Thus, in the case of the
Agrobacterium
opines, the formation of a Schiff’ s base can be followed by reduction (as for octopine), by the Pictet-Spengler reaction (as for cucumopine), or by Amadori rearrangement (as for mannopine).

sec.title: 4.8. Chrysopine synthase
4.9. Agrocinopine synthase
5. Origin of opine synthase genes
sec.p:
Most likely, the T-DNA opine synthesis genes were initially bacterial, catabolic genes, and became later incorporated into the T-DNA. Subsequently, they could have acquired eukaryotic promoters and anabolic, rather than catabolic, functions. This is suggested by the fact that some T-DNA opine synthesis enzymes are related to bacterial opine degradation enzymes. Mas2’ is related to MocD, and the N- and C-terminal ends of Mas1 ′ to MocE and MocC respectively (Kim et al., 1996a). MocC oxidizes mannopine to santhopine, and also carries out the reverse reaction, like Mas1’ (Kim et al., 1996). The T-DNA-encoded Ags enzyme is homologous to the catabolic mannopine cyclase AgcA (Hong, 1994; Hong and Farrand, 1994); both have the same enzymatic activity (Hong and Farrand, 1996). Acs is weakly homologous to the phosphodiesterase AccF (
). RolD (or Orf15) of
A. rhizogenes
is related to bacterial Ocd enzymes, like ArcB from
Agrobacterium
and
Rhizobium (Cho et al., 1996)
.

Based on sequence similarity, the opine synthase genes from
Agrobacterium
can be placed in 7 groups: ocs /
vis
/ nos / susD , susL / rolD , ags / chs , mis / cus ,
mas 1
’
,
mas 2
’
and acs .

sec.title: 6. Secretion of opines by transformed plant tissues
7. Opine synthase genes in natural GMOs
sec.p:
Opine synthesis genes identified in nGMOs are summarized in Table 1 . Taxonomically close species can have similar cT-DNAs, resulting from a single transformation event, and transmitted through different speciation steps, as proposed for
Nicotiana ( Otten, 2020 )
,
Linaria ( Matveeva and Lutova, 2014 )
and
Ipomoea (Quispe et al., 2019)
. Before presenting the opine synthase genes from nGMOs, we would like to stress an important point. New opine synthesis genes are generally named after known genes on the basis of sequence homology, not on the basis of the properties of the corresponding enzymes. Only a very limited number of studies have addressed the enzymatic properties of opine synthases. Thus, a new DNA sequence similar to a bona fide octopine synthase gene will be annotated as ocs , but the encoded enzyme might be unable to synthesize octopine because its substrate specificity differs. One possibility to indicate the lack of enzyme data is to use the suffix "-like” (as in octopine synthase-like or
ocl
), but automatic annotation does not use this possibility. The names for new opine synthase genes must therefore be considered as provisional, and the search for opines in nGMOs should be combined with studies on the enzymatic properties of the corresponding proteins.
As can be seen from the table, opine synthase genes are irregularly distributed between naturally transgenic species. susD is lacking, chs ,

ags , and nos are rare (1–2 genera). Representatives of 7 genera (from 6 families) contain homologs of
mas 1
’,
plants of 9 genera (from 7 families) contain
mas 2
′ -like sequences. However, only few of these genes are intact.
Citrus maxima
contains intact copies of both genes.
Luffa
and
Eucalyptus
contain an intact
mas 1
’
,
Salix
and
Nicotiana
contain an intact
mas 2
’
. In the remaining genera, the genes are incomplete, or contain premature stop codons or frameshifts. Homologs of mis (7 genera, and at least 9 transformation events) and cus (6 genera, and at least 7 transformation events) are also widespread. Several species carry intact copies of the weakly related mis and cus genes (8 for mis and 11 for cus ), or a mix of defective and intact copies. The high number of intact cus and mis genes suggests a special role for these genes in nGMOs. Homologs of susL-rolD (7), acs (7), and ocs-vis (6) are also prevalent.

A number of species contain multiple opine synthase genes, on one or several cT-DNAs. Genes for agrocinopine synthases ( acs ) combine with susL (in
P. andersonii , D. lotus
), cus (in
D. lotus
), ocs /
vis , mas 1
’,
and
mas 2
’
(in
N. otophora
). The acs / susL and acs / cus combinations are not surprising, since they have been described in agrobacterial strains. The combination of opine genes in
N. otophora
is unusual, and points to the existence of an as yet uncharacterized type of
Agrobacterium
strain.

The gene combination
mas 2
’
,
mas 1
’
and ags (found in
A. rhizogenes
15834) encodes agropine synthesis,
mas 2
’
,
mas 1
’
(
A. rhizogenes
8196) allow mannopine synthesis (see above). The first combination is found in
Nicotiana species
, the second in
P. guajava
.

Phylogenetic trees for individual opine genes from nGMOs and their homologs from
Agrobacterium
are shown in Figs. 1–9 . For these comparisons, we use a total of 92 different T-DNA regions extracted from 350
Agrobacterium
genomes (
). In some plants, the genome contains several copies of the same opine gene. They can be localized on the same cT-DNA and/or on different cT-DNAs. Genes present on the initial T-DNA can be amplified by the insertion of more than one copy and further amplification, as in the case of the
N. otophora TC and TE
cT-DNAs (Chen et al., 2018), leading to clustering of sequences on the tree.

sec.title: 7.1. acs genes
sec.p:
The phylogenetic relations between the acs sequences from
Agrobacterium
and species of the genera
Nicotiana
,
Diospyros
,
Populus
,
Parasponia , Camellia , Ipomoea
and
Linaria
are shown in Fig. 1 . Note that
Diospyros
plants received acs homologs from two or three different origins. Two copies of the gene cluster together with the
Linaria
sequence and genes from
A. rhizogenes LMG
63, ATCC 15834, and C16/80 and
A. salinitolerans CFBP
5507. The third
D. lotus
sequence is similar to
Camellia sinensis
and
Parasponia andersonia acs
genes and the resulting group is weakly related to known
Agrobacterium
sequences. The
Populus
sequence clusters with
A. rhizogenes
T155/95, while the
Ipomoea
and
Nicotiana otophora
sequences are related to a group of
Agrobacterium
strains composed of
A. genomosp
. 6 NCPPB925,
A. vitis CG
47 and CG474,
A. rhizogenes CA
84/95, and
A. larrymoorei CFBP
5477. Thus, acs genes in naturally transgenic plants are derived from a large variety of
Agrobacterium
strains.

sec.title: 7.2. ags and chs genes
sec.p:
The ags and chs genes are rare in nGMOs.
Nicotiana
sequences originally annotated as ags (Chen et al., 2014) are more related to chs ( Fig. 2 ). Thus, to date,
Eucalyptus
is the only species which contains a small ags gene fragment ( Table 1 ). It was not included in the phylogenetic tree due to its small size.

sec.title: 7.3. mas1 ’ and mas2 ’ genes
sec.p:
Sequences from
Salix , Luffa , Ipomoea , Eucalyptus
, and
Citrus
previously described as ags (
) were re-annotated as
mas 1
’
. The phylogenetic trees of
mas 2
’
and
mas 1
’
( Figs. 3 and 4 respectively) are similar, showing coevolution of these closely associated genes. In both cases, sequences from
Eucalyptus
form a separate cluster, and sequences from
Ipomoea , Luffa ,
and
Citrus
form a common cluster, together with
A. rhizogenes
8196 and ATCC15834. In the case of
mas 1
’, this cluster also includes the
Psidium
sequences, and in the case of
mas 2
’
, it includes
Nicotiana
(the
Psidium mas 2
’
fragment was not included in the analysis due to its short size). The
mas 1
’
and
mas 2
’ genes from
Salix
are more distant.

sec.title: Orphanage
Orphanage
sec.p: a This column is set to + if the genome contains at least one intact copy of the gene.

sec.title: 7.4. cus genes
sec.p:
The phylogenetic tree of the cus genes ( Fig. 5 ) shows sequences from
Agrobacterium
,
Diospyros
,
Dioscorea
,
Azadirachta
,
Arachis
,
Dianthus
, and a remarkable number of
Silene
sequences. The latter are highly clustered, suggesting a single insertion into the genome of the common ancestor of
S. latifolia
,
S. dioica
,
S. conica
,
S. undulata
, and
S. noctiflora
with subsequent divergence. Both
Silene
and
Dianthus
(carnation), the cus sequence of which is similar to the
Silene
sequences, belong to the Caryophyllaceae .

Homologs of the
Arachis
(peanut) cus gene form two related groups, corresponding to the A and B genomes (
). Within each group, the sequences are very similar. Probably, ancestors of genomes A and B were transformed independently with strains carrying similar cus genes.
Dioscorea alata
and
Diospyros lotus cus
genes cluster with the two known
Agrobacterium
sequences, the other cus sequences seem to be derived from other strain types .

sec.title: 7.5. mis genes
sec.p:
Fig. 6 shows the phylogenetic tree of the mis sequences from
Agrobacterium
,
Nicotiana
,
Linaria
,
Cuscuta
,
Pharnaceum
,
Kewa
,
Nissolia
, and
Aeschynomene
. There are five clusters corresponding to
Nicotiana
,
Linaria
,
Pharnaceum
/
Kewa
,
Nissolia
/
Aeschynomene
, and
Cuscuta
. Apparently, a strain with a mis gene close to 1724-mis transformed
Nicotiana
and
Linaria
. The other plant cus sequences form a separate group, derived from unknown types of
Agrobacterium
strains.

sec.title: 7.6. nos genes
sec.p:
Homologs of the nos gene are rare in nGMOs. They are found in
Eperua falcata
and
Salix purpurea
. They form a branch separate from the
Agrobacterium nos
genes ( Fig. 7 ).

sec.title: 7.7. ocs and vis genes
sec.p:
As the
vis
and ocs genes are closely related, we combine them in one analysis ( Fig. 8 ), which compares
Agrobacterium
,
Humulus
,
Parasponia
,
Trema
,
Eutrema
,
Morella
and
Nicotiana
sequences. The
Agrobacterium vis
and ocs genes (gene names as based on the sequence annotations) are indicated by one or two asterisks respectively.
Humulus
,
Parasponia
, and
Trema
sequences cluster together with pTi82143-
vis
and CG98-
vis
. The
Humulus
sequences are clearly derived from a single insert.
Eutrema yunnanense ocs
is similar to CA84/95- ocs and ICMP 5856T- ocs . The
Morella rubra
gene (annotated as
vis
) clusters together with
Nicotiana ocl
(octopine synthase-like) sequences; both are only weakly related to
Agrobacterium vis
and ocs sequences and might well have different substrate specificities.

sec.title: 7.8. susL and rolD genes
sec.p:
The phylogenetic tree of the susL and rolD genes ( Fig. 9 ) shows sequences of
Agrobacterium
( susL : one asterisk, rolD two asterisks),
Parasponia
(on 5 different cT-DNAs,
),
Trema
(2 cT-DNAs,
),
Camellia
,
Diospyros
,
Juglans
,
Cyclocarya
,
Euphorbia
,
Quillaja
,
Boswellia
,
Nicotiana
, and
Ipomoea
. Sequences from the Juglandaceae family (
Juglans
and
Cyclocarya
) and
Quillaja
form a closely related group, while sequences from
Parasponia
and
Diospyros
are found widely throughout the tree, showing multiple transformation events from diverse
Agrobacterium
sources. Three clades with
Parasponia rolD
/ susL sequences can be distinguished. The first one contains
Parasponia
,
Trema
, and
Camellia
sequences, the second one genes from
Parasponia
and
Diospyros ,
and the last one, only genes from
Parasponia
. It is interesting to note that a similar clustering of
Parasponia
and
Camellia
sequences was noted for the acs gene ( Fig. 1 ). These data indicate that these plants were transformed by similar strains. With regard to the
Agrobacterium
sequences, it can be noted that two out of four
Diospyros lotus
sequences resemble the C16/80 and T5/73 rolD sequences, whereas the other plant rolD / susL genes show relatively little similarity to
Agrobacterium
sequences, indicating that they were transformed by unknown
Agrobacterium
types .

sec.title: 8. Opines in natural GMOs
sec.p: Up to now, no opine synthase enzymes were purified directly from nGMOs in order to study their properties, and only few attempts have been made to detect the expected opines. We expect that these studies will show significant developments in the near future.

The first study to identify opines in nGMOs was carried out in
N. glauca
, after it was found to contain an intact Ngmis gene (
). Ngmis expression in
E. coli
yielded an active enzyme producing mikimopine in vitro . However, no mikimopine could be detected in
N. glauca ( Suzuki et al., 2002 )
. In a second study of this type , the TB-
mas 2
’
gene from
N. tabacum
was expressed from a constitutive promoter in
N. benthamiana
, which led to the production of a deoxyfructosylglutamine (dfg)-like compound (Chen et al., 2014). A few
N. tabacum
cultivars were found to express TB-
mas 2
’
to high levels in roots, most showed only very low expression.
N. benthamiana
plants transformed with a β- glucuronidase (GUS) reporter gene under control of the TB-
mas 2
’
promoter showed specific expression in root tips. Extracts from root tips of high expresser
N. tabacum
cultivars contained significant levels of dfg, those of low expressers did not (Chen et al., 2016). A remarkable study on the cT-DNA mis gene of
Cuscuta suaveolens
showed various aspects of its function. Cuscuta- mis is expressed in different
Cuscuta
tissues. A Cuscuta- mis promoter-GUS construct revealed expression in haustoria, flowers and roots. Expressed in
E. coli
, the Cuscuta -mis gene produced an enzyme which could synthesize mikimopine in vitro . Cuscuta- mis expression in
Arabidopsis thaliana
transformants led to mikimopine synthesis, and finally,
C. suaveolens
itself was found to contain mikimopine (Zhang et al., 2020b).

sec.title: 9. Questions and tasks ahead
sec.p: Many plant species are naturally transformed and carry a large variety of T-DNA genes. The conservation of 45 intact open reading frames for opine synthesis genes across a range of different plant families suggests a role for opine synthesis in such plants. Mikimopine synthase genes are the most promising candidates. Based on the analysis of phylogenetic trees based on T-DNA and cT-DNA gene sequences, it is possible to make assumptions about the strains that were involved in the natural transformation of plants and about their host specificity.

It will be important to know whether nGMO opine genes are biologically active and what the consequences could be for metabolism and growth. The opine synthesis genes seem to be conserved, suggesting a benefit to the plant. This could be through attraction of beneficial, opine-utilizing bacteria or other organisms, or through a direct effect on the plant’ s metabolism, without intervention of other organisms. Research on nGMO opines has only just started, but the earlier opine studies presented in this review provide a good basis for rapid progress in this field. Starting from an nGMO opine gene sequence, we propose the following steps.
1. Expression of the gene in a heterologous system and purification of the enzyme using a removable tag.

2. Studies on the catalytic properties of the enzyme, testing different substrates under different conditions, including cofactors. Possible reversibility of the synthetic reactions and product inhibition will be of relevance to studies in planta. The already characterized
Agrobacterium
enzymes can provide a useful guideline to the types of substrates to be tested. Studies on enzyme 3D structure and ligand binding, as done for mollusk OcDH (
) will allow further insight in the enzymatic mechanisms of opine synthesis. It may be important to also investigate various associated non-enzymatic reactions, especially in the case of the Amadori compounds.

3. Extensive studies on the regulation of nGMO opine gene expression, using transcription data and reporter gene analysis. These studies should reveal tissue and cell type specificity, growth phase dependence, inducibility by various endogenous and exogenous factors, and (possibly) induction and repression by substrates and products. The transcription factors required for expression of opine genes (both activation and repression) could also be studied.
4. Presence and turn-over of opine enzymes in planta , using antibodies.

5. A search for opines in planta. Previous studies on
Agrobacterium
genes or with purified enzymes can provide a first indication what kind of structures might be expected. In most cases, opine enzymes will catalyze the synthesis of a group of related opines, with possibly further modifications by plant enzymes, or by spontaneous, non-enzymatic reactions. Gene expression studies may orient investigations on opine content to particular parts of the plant, and to favorable expression conditions.

6. Labelling studies to determine the rate of opine synthesis, further modifications and degradation. It will be important to determine how, where, and to what level, different opines accumulate in nGMOs, as has been studied for crown gall and hairy root tissues (
). Such studies should also consider transport within the plant, and could lead to the discovery of specific transport and retention mechanisms, and reveal the existence of opine sources (production areas) and sinks (accumulation areas) within plants, at various stages of development.

7. Detailed investigations on the effects of opine synthesis on the host plant. These would include possible changes in the metabolism of opine substrates and their pools (for example modifications of lysine and pyruvate metabolism in the case of lysopine) and the metabolic cost, effects of opines on gene expression, and on growth and morphogenesis. This type of investigation will require plants with active opine genes and control plants without. In this type of investigation, opine synthase genes under inducible promoter control, enabling control of opine synthesis and accumulation, may be of considerable interest. The tobacco
TBmas2 ’
gene is expressed in root tips where it could reduce the pools of glucose and glutamine. This could be detrimental to cell division in the root meristem, where these compounds are required in high amounts. More generally, opine synthesis could reduce growth in specific ways and patterns, thereby influencing plant morphogenesis. There is some evidence for this in the case of RolD (
;
,
; Bettini et al., 2003).
8. Studies on opine secretion by roots and other organs (like secretory glandular hairs) or by wounds, and on opine accumulation in the rhizosphere.

10. In a wider sense, effects of nGMO-controlled opine synthesis on other organisms might become interesting topics. Opines could constitute a source of nutrition, act as flavors (like fructose-amino acid derivatives,
), pollinator attractants, or toxins. They could also attract animals which might eat such plants and disperse their seeds. They may have played a role in the early domestication of some plant species used in agriculture, like sweet potato, yam, tea, citrus or hops, if they contribute to flavor. Inactivation of the opine genes in these species by CRISPR-Cas9 could rapidly provide some answers to these questions.
